metadata.h1: Data Crafting: Why We All Should Play With Data
metadata.description: I recently led a workshop on Data Crafting. The idea (of getting our hands dirty by crafting with data) spontaneously arose in a conversation between myself and Natalie Vladis, a Quantitative Fellow…

all_paragraphs: I recently led a workshop on Data Crafting. The idea (of getting our hands dirty by crafting with data) spontaneously arose in a conversation between myself and Natalie Vladis, a Quantitative Fellow at Harvard Medical School.

Here’s what happened: Natalie loves crafting and lives in data. I love data visualization, occasionally hodgepodge things, and believe that adults don’t play enough. In the month of January, we wanted to facilitate a creative, hands-on play date with data — to make data approachable AND to build a space where experts can explore new facets of their data.

The value of play is scientifically grounded. But play in the context of data? That’s relatively new. Most literature in the space focuses on building data literacy in children, and while design has often integrated facets of play to inspire new work, it’s failed to effectively trickle down into its interdisciplinary neighbor, data visualization.

Play comes from curiosity, inquiry, and exploration. By latching on to curiosity and allowing ourselves to explore, we learn new techniques without the stress of expectation or competition, and uncover unknown facets of the world. This is particularly important when we are intimidated by something, or when we have become accustomed to it, associating it with the mundane.
But we think data is austere — perfect — and that makes it hard to play with.

Combine the perceived complexity of data that the general populace maintains (an internalized belief, if you will) with visualizations’ rhetorical force — a major reason why we find it difficult to fact check, debug, and critique them — and we find a conundrum: data and its representations are unapproachable.

By that, I mean data, as an intangible, big concept, is scary. People avoid it. And those that work regularly with data (as analysts, researchers, and scientists) often only understand one idea, one perspective, of what data is and are therefore limited in the ways they can represent and engage with said data. Because again, data feels hard to play with.
That’s how Data Crafting came into being. Data should be fun, should be approachable, should be played with. The best way Natalie and I could think to make that happen is by crafting.
But first why crafting? What is crafting? And how does it differ from data physicalization?

“Craft is the dovetailing of discipline and imagination, dedication and inspiration. When those spiral around each other, and serious attention is given over to that alchemy, then one’s craft can be realized” — Rosanne Cash

Historically, a craft was a skilled labor, maintaining traditional arts for future viewers. In response to harmful factory conditions of the 19th century, definitions of craft evolved to become counter-industrial, elevating the well-being of both consumer and producer. Then (in the 20th century) studio craft added new meaning: a rebellion against conformity.

Our modern understanding of craft builds on traditional arts — from quilting and beyond. Craft acts as a form of individual agency via the creation of anything, regardless of material or technique, from custom-made chairs to craft beers to handmade pompoms. Most importantly, modern crafting is something anyone can do.
Let’s revisit our initial question: what is Data Crafting? It’s representing data, where there is:
An argument of accessibility. While engaging with multiple mediums may facilitate connections with a broader audience, there is much work to be done in the space of accessible data representations.

But how does Data Crafting differ from data physicalization? To Nathalie and I, it’s in the play of it. As the Data Physicalization Wiki puts it, “Physical representations of data have existed for thousands of years.” Incan Quipus, Marshall Island Stick Charts, and Yakama Time Balls are a handful of examples to illustrate this point. From a historic perspective, these are products of data crafting.

Data Physicalization has been redefined in the research community to describe computer-supported physical data representations. In the cases where a computer isn’t involved, the representation is still carefully curated and appears “perfect”. As we’ve discussed, perceived perfection makes it hard to play.
While there is certainly overlap between data physicalization and data crafting, the emphasis on play is absent in physicalization. And that’s what we were so excited about!

We describe data crafting as either adjacent to or a subset of data physicalization, where the emphasis is not on a perfect, camera-ready object but rather on the process of doing — of playing with your hands, and experiencing with all five senses.

Because, as Albert Einstein once said, “Play is the highest form of research.” When data is the foundation of all research, how can we not want to play with it? With that in mind, I encourage you all to play with data — and maybe craft a bit ;)

This is one of two articles that I’ll be writing about Data Crafting. This first article lays the ground for why we wanted to craft with data. The next explores how we did it, and shares a few takeaways so that you too can play with data. Stay tuned!
